awd_titl_txt: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds U Kei Cheang of Drexel University to conduct a research project, entitled "Investigation of microswimming in biological fluid environment," during the summer of 2012 at Ewha University in Seoul and Hanyang University in Seoul.  The host scientists are Professor Sungsu Park and Professor Jaebum Choo.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the understanding of the effects and relative importance of the many interactions influencing microbial transport in complex biomaterials. This is a challenging problem requiring a unique and innovative approach combining fluid mechanics, solid mechanics, microbiology, microfabrication, and digital image processing. The results of this work promise to establish the base of knowledge needed to properly understand microbial locomotion in a variety biological, health, environmental, and agricultural scenarios. In addition, the proposed work has the potential to transform understanding of locomotion and propulsion in realistic environments. Complex media affect microbial roles in infection, fertility, ecology, and environmental applications (such as bioremediation of pollutants and drinking water contamination). Demonstration of artificial bacteria control in synthetic bio-environment and establishing biological relevance through live cell comparison could have great impact on biology and engineering.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Helical swimmers are biological inspired by the spiral swimming exhibited by bacteria; specifically, spirochete’s form of swimming. Through non-conventional micro/nano-fabrication methods, several research groups had fabricated micro size helical structures. However, there are no given standards for fabricating such a complex geometries such as the helix. Previous work in FIB deposition methods had demonstrated the capability to fabricate helical nanostructures with relative ease and repeatability. This project aims to fabricate nanoscale helical swimmers that can be controlled wirelessly through magnetic field. The objective during the project duration was to identity the parameters and conditions to fabricate nano helix.

 

The optimal structural parameters for the helical swimmer were computed using COMSOL. After the preliminary design process, the optimized helical structure was fabricated using FIB deposition of carbon on silicon substrate. The helical body of the swimmer was designed, based on the optimized structural parameters using a 3D CAD software. The 3D model was then sliced into many cross section images. The FIB system deposited material layer by layer based on the sliced images to reconstruct the helical swimmer. As a result, helical nano-structures were successfully fabrication. Afterward, a nanoscale coating of metal was coated on the surface of the swimmer(s) using thermo and electron beam evaporator. This metal coating is useful for magnetic control in the latter stages of the project. Simultaneous to the simmer fabrication process, a Helmholtz coil setup was designed and built. The coil setup will be mounted onto the stage of a microscope for precise micro-control of the helical swimmers.

 

Future works include controlling the helical swimmers in a PMDS chamber under a magnetic field generated by the Helmholtz coil setup. The swimmers will be observed under a microscope and their activities will be recorded using a high speed camera. The captured videos will be analysis to investigation the swimming capability and controllability of the helical swimmers.


Last Modified: 11/30/2012
Modified by: U K Cheang

Image
  • Nanoscale helical structure created using FIB deposition of carbon.
    Hang-Eun Joe and U Kei Cheang
    Copyrighted
    U K Cheang
    Nano-Helix
